title: Manage the data domains list
content:
The system stores all data domains in the Data domains list. As the tenant admin, you can directly update the out-of-the-box (OOB) list in the Lists Management module. However, if you have many data domains, use the Export and Import features to manage your data domains in an easier way. 

The Export and Import features process data domain values for English (US) and other supported languages. 

Notes:

  • By default, all Service Management tenants come with a single data domain named Public.
  • Each tenant can have up to 1,000 data domains. When you reach this limit, the system disables the Add button in the List items area. Pagination occurs when there are more than 250 data domains. 
  • There is no option to define the order of the items in the data domains list. The system always adds new list items to the end of the existing list. 

Update the OOB data domains list

If you have a limited number of data domains, you can directly update the OOB data domains list with your custom values. 

To update the list: 

  1. Log in to the agent interface as the tenant admin.
  2. Go to Administration > Configuration > Lists to open the Data domains list. 
  3. Click Add, enter a name and display label, and then click OK or Add Another to add one or more custom data domains. 
  4. If you want to disable any OOB or custom data domains, clear the Active check box for them. Note that you can't disable the Public domain.  
  5. Click Save to save the list. 

Import custom data domains

If your system needs to use many custom data domains, instead of adding them one by one in the Lists Management module, you can import them as a .zip file.

Notes:

  • To avoid import failures, you can export the existing data domains list from the system as a .zip file and then use the exported XLS files in the .zip file as templates when preparing your own data for import.
  • When editing an XLS file, make sure that the file contains no empty rows. Note that clearing contents from a row will create an empty row. To avoid this issue, delete the row instead of clearing the contents.
  • When creating a zip file with the updated XLS files, pay attention to the following:
    • You must name each XLS file as DataDomains_<language_code>.xls.
    • You must place the XLS files directly under the zip package instead of in any subfolders.
    • You must include at least the DataDomains_en.xls file in the zip file; the XLS files for other languages are optional.
  • Imported data domains will override the existing ones in the system. Items that exist in the system but not in the imported list become inactive after the import (the only exception is the Public data domain, which you can't disable). 

To import your custom data domains:

  1. Log in to Suite Administration as suite-admin: https://<External Access Host>/bo.
  2. Open your tenant,  go to the Application settings tab, and make sure that .zip is in the Attachment allowlist field. If it's not there, add it. You can remove it after the import.  
  3. Log in to the agent interface as the tenant admin.
  4. Go to Administration > Lists to open the Data domains list. 
  5. Click Save in case you have made any edits to the OOB list.  
  6. Click Export. The system exports the list of data domains to a zip file (DataDomains_YYYYMMDD_XXXXXXX.zip), which is automatically downloaded to your download folder. The zip file contains a set of XLS files for supported languages. These files are named DataDomains_<language_code>.xls, such as DataDomains_fr.xls. 
    Note: The Active column only appears in the English version (DataDomains_en.xls) to ensure the data consistency.
  7. The DataDomains_en.xls file is mandatory when you import custom data domains later. Edit this file in the following columns: 
    • Name: Must start with a capital letter, may contain A–Z, a–z, 0–9, and must not contain any spaces. For example: IT.  Note that Service Management automatically appends _c to the imported Name values. 
    • Display Label: the display name of the data domain. For example: IT. Note that you must provide Name and Display Label values as pairs; otherwise, errors will occur during import. 
    • Active: true or false
      Note:       Make sure only the Active column exists only in the English version (DataDomains_en.xls).  
  8. Optionally, edit the DataDomains_en-GB.xls file by copying the Name and Display Label values from the DataDomains_en.xls file and update the display labels to British English if needed. 
  9. Optionally, update the XLS files for other desired languages by copying the Name and Display Label values from the DataDomains_en.xls file, and then have the display labels localized. Note that each localization XLS file must include the same set or a subset of Name values as the English XLS file. If a localization file contains a Name that doesn't exist in the DataDomains_en.xls file, the import won't fail but will ignore the localized display label for that Name. 
  10. Compress the updated XLS files to a zip file without including any subfolders. The zip file must contain at least the DataDomains_en.xls file, and a localization XLS file must contain at least one localized display label value.  
  11. Return to the Lists Management module, open the Data domains list and then click Import. Browse to your zip file, and then click Import.  
  12. Check that your custom data domains and their translated values have been imported successfully. To view the localized values of an item, select the item from the list, click Edit, and click the More (...) icon next to the Display name field. 
  13. Click Save to save the imported data.
    Note: If you want to discard the imported data, click Discard.
